text: Inflow to a reservoir is all of the water that flows into the reservoir from rain and snow melt. It is measured in "cfs" which stands for "cubic feet per second" and is the average rate of water flow into the reservoir. It is equal to a volume of water one foot high and one foot wide flowing a distance of one foot in one second, so one "cfs" is equal to 7.48 gallons of water flowing each second.

image_text: For instance, in 2011, there was a big rainstorm in the end of December that contributed to substantial reservoir inflow, and then the reservoir had steady inflow from melting snow from mid-March all the way through June.

text: Outflow from a reservoir is all of the water that flows out of a reservoir. It is measured in cfs, just like inflow. Outflow is controlled by reservoir operators who balance reserving adequate water in the reservoir with keeping space in the reservoir for future storms or melted snow.

image_text: For instance, a lot of water was outflowed from the reservoir in mid-March of 2011 to make room for all of the snowmelt.
During the drought years, from 2010 to 2016, there was very little inflow into the reservoir.

There are four ways that water can outflow from the reservoir.
The emergency spillway: Used for the first time over the weekend but the hillside began dangerously eroding within a day after taking on releases that peaked at 12,600 cfs.
Main spillway: Damaged February 7, can release up to 150,000 cfs of water but dam operators were releasing about 100,000 cfs in the days after the spillway was damaged.

Edward Hyatt Powerplant: 14,000 cfs can push through the hydroelectric plan at the base of the dam when operational but it was turned off to prevent it from being damaged after the main spillway was damaged.

River outlet: Located lowest in the reservoir, regulates cold-water releases. It had an original capacity of 5,400 cfs but has largely not been used since it was involved in a 2009 accident that infured dam workers. Officials say it can now release up to 2,000 cfs.
